awd_titl_txt: Tailoring Exchange Interactions in Complex Oxide Heterostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Many current commercial products such as giant magnetoresistive sensors that are used in magnetic random-access memory and magnetic hard drives are based on the interactions of magnetic forces between multiple materials. A better understanding of these interactions may also allow for the development of future spintronic devices. This project explores the unique interfacial phenomena found in complex oxide structures in order to design artificially-layered materials with tailored magnetic properties. Outreach activities include supporting the University of California at Davis Community College Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Transfer Day which targets educationally disadvantaged and underrepresented groups from Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement programs across Northern California. A parallel and equally important impact of this project is the training of young scientists and engineers in a field that lies at the intersection of traditional disciplines of Materials Science and Engineering, Physics, and Electrical Engineering. Graduates typically find employment in the information technology sector. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This goal of this project is to develop a fundamental understanding of interfacial phenomena in complex oxide heterostructures to design artificially-layered material with tailored magnetic properties. The incorporation of these materials in next generation spintronic and orbitronic devices has the potential for significant improvements in device speed and energy efficiency, which may transform the information storage and technology sectors. This work utilizes laser-assisted growth to control interfacial properties with atomic layer precision in combination with sophisticated techniques for characterizing their structural, chemical, and functional properties over multiple length scales. In addition, geometric confinement effects as these materials are patterned to nanoscale dimensions are investigated. These results enable the development of predictive models of the emergent interfacial properties at dimensions relevant for device applications. Additional education activities include the training of undergraduate and graduate students in state-of-the-art tools, including synchrotron radiation and neutron scattering-based characterization techniques at U.S. national laboratories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Manipulating electronic or magnetic properties of quantum materials has the potential for addressing ever-increasing technological demands of next generation computing devices such as neuromorphic computing, Internet of Things, artificial intelligence, and cloud computing. The control of magnetic spin textures, i.e., the spatial variation of the orientation of magnetic moments in an antiferromagnetic or ferromagnetic material has received significant interest in this context in recent years due to the desire to harness both the spin and charge degrees of freedom of electrons to achieve greater energy efficiency and superior device functionality. Within the family of quantum materials, complex oxides such as the ABO3 perovskite structure present as an exciting playground for such studies due to their strong interactions between the charge, spin, lattice, and orbital degrees of freedom. Modern synthesis techniques enable the fabrication of ultrathin epitaxial thin films and heterostructures composed of alternating layers, each with its own functional property, with a well-defined structure (crystallographic orientation, layer thickness, minimal interface roughness), and designed to exploit interactions at and across interfaces. These interfacial interactions include structural, chemical, electronic, and magnetic effects and they have been shown to lead to emergent phenomena not found in the constituent materials.

The Intellectual Merit of this project involved developing a fundamental understanding of interfacial phenomena and geometric confinement effects in complex oxide heterostructures and nanostructures to design artificially-layered material with tailored magnetic properties. This work utilized laser-assisted growth to control interfacial properties with atomic layer precision in combination with sophisticated techniques for characterizing their structural, chemical, and functional properties over multiple length scales. In particular, this work leveraged the unique capabilities of synchrotron x-ray-based characterization tools available at the Advanced Light Source/Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource/SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, as well as neutron scattering techniques available at the Spallation Neutron Source/Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Interfaces between perovskite oxides, exemplified by La1−xSrxCoO3−δ/La1−xSrxMnO3−δ (LSCO/LSMO) bilayers, exhibit unconventional magnetic exchange switching behavior characterized by the formation of an interfacial LSCO layer with magnetically active Co2+ ions and an increased concentration of oxygen vacancies. This interfacial behavior was found to depend sensitively on factors such as the LSCO and LSMO layer thicknesses, stacking order, and epitaxial strain. Additional work utilized an ion implantation-based characterization technique to define micro- and nanoscale structures and demonstrated that complex oxides can display unique phenomena not found in their metallic magnetic counterparts. The spin textures in these systems involved a delicate balance between multiple magnetic energy terms, including magnetocrystalline anisotropy, exchange energy, magnetostatic energy, exchange coupling interactions, and spin-orbit coupling. In artificial spin ice structures, this energic balance resulted in the formation of complex spin textures consisting of single and double vortex domains instead of Ising domains, which lead to fundamentally different short- and long-range interactions between neighboring nanomagnets.

The Broader Impacts of this work involved workforce development of the next generation of materials researchers by giving undergraduate and graduate students firsthand experience with key skills in materials growth and characterization, with strong exposure to the unique facilities available at Department of Energy user facilities. Research outcomes from this work were disseminated through numerous publications, conference presentations, and by their incorporation in courses taught within the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at UC Davis. In addition, outreach activities were coordinated with the UC Davis Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement Center which prepares students for academically rigorous colleges and universities by helping them excel in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) subjects. The college preparation program sparks early interest in STEM by bridging classroom concepts to real-world practice and inspires middle and high school students to higher education and successful careers.

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2024
Modified by: Yayoi Takamura
